questions.text: The total number of bones present in the axial skeleton and appendicular skeleton in an adult human being is ______ and ______, respectively.
questions.solution:
In the adult, 80 bones are present in the axial skeleton, and 126 bones in the appendicular skeleton. 

Region  Number Bones
Skull 28
  • Cranial bones (8)
  • Facial bones (14)
  • Auditory ossicles (6)
Hyoid 1
  •  Hyoid bone (1)
Vertebral column 26
  • Cervical vertebrae (7)
  • Thoracic vertebrae (12)
  • Lumbar vertebrae (5)
  • Sacrum (1)
  • Coccyx (1)
Thoracic cage 25
  • Ribs (24)
  • Sternum (1)
Axial Skeleton - 80 
Pectoral girdle 4
  • Clavicle (2)
  • Scapula (2)
Upper extremity 60
  • Humerus (2)
  • Radius (2)
  • Ulna (2)
  • Carpals (16)
  • Metacarpals (10)
  • Phalanges (28)
Pelvic girdle 2
  • Hip bones (2)
Lower extremity 60  
  • Femur (2)
  • Tibia (2)
  • Fibula (2)
  • Patella (2)
  • Tarsals (14)
  • Metatarsals (10)
  • Phalanges (28)
Appendicular Skeleton - 126

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding bones is false?

choices.text: Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone
Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts
Bone mainly contains type 2 collagen fibres
Calcium phosphate is the major inorganic mineral

questions.solution:
Bone mainly contains type 1 collagen fibres. Bones are made up of mineralized collagenous extracellular matrix around specialized cells.

The extracellular matrix is composed of:

  • Organic component - around 30% of the organic matrix of bone is made up of collagen, mainly type 1 collagen.
  • Inorganic component - the major inorganic mineral in the bone matrix is calcium phosphate in the form of microcrystalline hydroxyapatite.

The specialized cells are:

  • Osteoblasts - responsible for the synthesis, deposition, and mineralization of the bone matrix. Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts. Osteoblasts get embedded in the matrix to become osteocytes.
  • Osteocytes - major cell type of a mature bone and is distributed throughout the matrix. They have lost the ability to divide or to secrete new matrix.
  • Osteoclasts - responsible for the local removal of bone during bone growth and remodelling.

questions.text: Which of the following is a modified long bone?
questions.solution:
The clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. e.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.  
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. e.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. e.g., clavicle.

The following image shows a graphical illustration of a typical long bone:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
questions.solution:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid bone. 

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum - Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum - Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a ​pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
The maxilla is a pneumatic bone. 

Pneumatic bones contain air-filled cavities, which make them light-weight. They also aid in the resonance of sound and act as air conditioning chambers for inspired air. e.g., maxilla, sphenoid, ethmoid, etc. 

Short bones: Carpal bones and tarsal bones

Flat bones: Sternum, ribs, scapula, and bones of the skull vault

Irregular bones: Hip bones, vertebra, and bones in the base of the skull.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes fabella?
questions.solution:
Fabella is a sesamoid bone. This term is used to describe a bone embedded within a tendon or a muscle. It is a variant of normal anatomy present in 10% to 30% of individuals. Fabella is found within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral condyle.

Important sesamoid bones:

  • Patella - largest sesamoid bone in the tendon of quadriceps femoris.
  • Pisiform - tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • Fabella - lateral head of the gastrocnemius. 
  • Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metacarpal within the tendons of flexor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis.
  • Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metatarsophalangeal articulation within the double tendon of flexor hallucis brevis.

The X-ray image below depicts the fabella (marked with an arrow).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding long bones?

choices.text: Cancellous bone is absent in the epiphysis
Cancellous bone is present in the outer cortex
Haversian system is absent in cancellous bone
Compact bone has lamellae arranged in a meshwork

questions.solution:
The Haversian system is seen in compact bones, not cancellous bones. 

Based on their macroscopic structure, bones can be classified as compact and cancellous (spongy) bones. 

Compact bones are composed of cylindrical structural units called Haversian systems or osteons. Each Haversian system contains a central canal within which the small blood vessels, nerves, and endosteum are present. This canal is surrounded by multiple layers or lamellae of the calcified matrix containing type I collagen fibers. These canals communicate with each other by Volkmann's canal.

The lamellae of the cancellous/spongy bone are arranged in a meshwork, and hence do not form Haversian systems.

The diaphysis and outer cortex of long bones are predominantly made of compact bone, while the epiphysis and inner medulla are predominantly made of cancellous bone.

Related Pearl: Differences between Compact and Cancellous bones

The table below shows the differences between Compact and Cancellous bones:

 

Compact bone

Cancellous (spongy) bone

Location

Outer Cortex

Inner Medulla

Lamellae

Arranged to form Harversian system

Arranged in a meshwork, so Haversian systems are absent

Bone marrow

Yellow, stores fat after puberty. It is red before puberty

Red, produce RBCs, granular series of WBC and platelets

Nature

Hard and ivory like

Spongy

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented to your OPD with progressive swelling and worsening knee pain over the past 2 months. An X-ray reveals the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding the layer of bone involved?

choices.text: Progenitor cells are present in the outer fibrous layer
It is continuous with the capsule of the joint
It is devoid of nerve supply

questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows Codman's triangle, which is due to an irregular periosteal reaction (outermost layer), commonly seen in patients with osteosarcoma. The periosteum is a thick fibrous membrane that covers the outer surface of all bones, except at the joint surfaces and insertion points of tendons and ligaments (entheses). At the articular margin, the periosteum is continuous with the capsule of the joint.

The periosteum has 2 layers: 

  • The outer fibrous layer - contains fibroblasts.
  • The inner cambium layer (osteogenic layer) - contains progenitor cells that develop into osteoblasts.

Periosteum gets nourishment from periosteal arteries. It has a rich nerve supply, which makes it the most sensitive part of the bone.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do the Sharpey's fibers connect?
questions.solution:
Sharpey's fibers are thick collagen fibers that connect the periosteum to the underlying bone. 

Sharpey's fibers are present in the bone and the teeth. 

  • Bone - tether the periosteum to the underlying bone. 
  • Teeth - connect the cementum to the periosteum of the alveolar bone (tooth socket).

questions.text: Which of the following bones develops through intramembranous ossification?
questions.solution:
Frontal bones undergo intramembranous ossification. Other bones listed have enchondral ossification. 

Based on their development, bones can be classified into 3 categories: 

  1. Membranous bones (dermal bones) are formed through intramembranous ossification. There is direct bone formation within highly vascular sheets or ‘membranes’ derived from mesenchymal condensations. e.g., bones of the facial skeleton including the frontal, lacrimal, zygomatic, and nasal bones. 
  2. Cartilaginous bones are formed by intra-cartilaginous (enchondral) ossification. Bone forms by ossification of preformed hyaline cartilage model. This is the main method of bone formation in the body. e.g., bones of limbs, vertebral column, and thoracic cage. 
  3. Membranocartilaginous bones ossify from both cartilage and mesenchymal condensation. e.g., clavicle, mandible, occipital bone, temporal bone, sphenoid bone, etc.

questions.text: The structure that the marked muscle in the gluteal region inserts into has ____ type of epiphysis?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and its insertion is at the greater trochanter of the femur, which is an example of traction epiphysis.

Traction epiphysis is nonarticular and does not transmit weight. They provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis. Examples of traction epiphysis include greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur. 

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: While assessing a child with short stature, the senior resident orders an X-ray to better evaluate the structure marked X in the radiograph. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this structure?

choices.text: It is made of elastic cartilage
It is supplied only by epiphyseal arteries
It is the site for enchondral ossification

questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the radiograph is the epiphyseal plate. It is the site for enchondral ossification that is mainly responsible for the growth of long bones. 

The epiphyseal plate (growth plate) is a hyaline cartilage layer that separates the epiphysis from the metaphysis. It receives nourishment from both the epiphyseal and metaphyseal arteries. Fractures involving epiphyseal plates are known as Salter-Harris fractures. 

The growing ends of bones include:

  • Upper limb: Upper end of humerus, and lower ends of radius and ulna
  • Lower limb: Lower end of femur, and upper end of tibia

questions.text: 'The secondary ossification center that appears first, fuses last'. Which of the following bones violates this law?
questions.solution:
The fibula violates the law of ossification which states that the secondary ossification center that appears first is the last to fuse.

The secondary ossification center at the lower end of the fibula appears before the ossification center of the upper end and fuses before the upper end.

Ossification centers are of two types:

  1. Primary centers appear before birth, usually during late embryonic or early fetal life (seventh week to the fourth month). They form the diaphysis.
  2. Secondary centers usually appear after birth. They form the epiphysis.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the bone is not nourished by the nutrient artery?
questions.solution:
The nutrient artery does not nourish the outer one-third of the cortex.

The nutrient artery enters the bone shaft through the nutrient foramen and runs obliquely through the cortex.

Blood supply of the Bone
Artery Regions supplied
Nutrient artery  Medullary cavity, inner 2/3 of the cortex, metaphysis
Metaphyseal arteries Metaphysis and growth plate
Epiphyseal arteries Epiphysis and growth plate
Periosteal arteries Periosteum, outer 1/3 of the cortex

Nutrient arteries of the long bones are directed away from the dominant growing epiphysis as the growing bone might pull and rupture the artery. So the nutrient foramina are directed away from the growing end. The direction of the nutrient artery can be remembered by the axiom 'To the elbow, I go, from the knee I flee'.

questions.text: In which of the following parts of the bone are hairpin bends of end arteries abundantly present?
questions.solution:
Hairpin bends of end arteries are seen abundantly in the metaphysis.

The metaphysis is the portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and diaphysis. It is the zone of active growth and is highly vascular. Before epiphysial fusion, the metaphysis is richly supplied through end arteries that form 'hairpin' bends.

The metaphysis is the most common location for osteomyelitis in children because the bacteria or emboli are easily trapped in the hairpin bends, thereby causing infection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cartilage is false?
questions.solution:
Articular cartilage despite being a type of hyaline cartilage lacks perichondrium.

Cartilage is a connective tissue composed of cells (chondrocytes) and fibers (collagen or yellow elastic fibers). These are embedded in a firm, gel-like matrix that is rich in mucopolysaccharides. It is much more elastic than bone. Cartilage does not have blood vessels or lymphatics. Chondrocytes get their nutrition by diffusion. Cartilage has no nerves and is insensitive.

There are three types of cartilages:

  1. Hyaline cartilage
  2. Elastic cartilage
  3. Fibrocartilage

Hyaline cartilage (except the subtype of articular cartilage) and elastic cartilage have perichondrium. Fibrocartilage does not have perichondrium.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: Which of the following does not have yellow cartilage?
questions.solution:
The septal nasal cartilage has hyaline cartilage and not yellow (elastic) cartilage.

Elastic cartilage (or yellow cartilage) contains a matrix rich in fine yellow elastic fibers containing the protein elastin. It is present in:

  1. Apices of arytenoid
  2. Epiglottis
  3. Corniculate cartilages
  4. Cuneiform cartilages
  5. Eustachian tube
  6. Pinna (Auricle)
  7. External auditory meatus 

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: What is the type of cartilage found in the structure marked X in the following radiograph?
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the pubic symphysis and the type of cartilage seen is fibrocartilage.

Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of fibrous and cartilaginous components make this tissue extremely tough and resilient. Fibrocartilage is present in the following sites:

  1. Pubic symphysis
  2. Manubriosternal joint
  3. Articular discs of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joints
  4. Anulus fibrosus of intervertebral discs
  5. Menisci of the knee
  6. Acetabular labrum
  7. Glenoid labrum
  8. The lining of bony grooves for tendons

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: In which of the following cartilages is type I collagen predominantly seen?
questions.solution:
Fibrocartilage predominantly contains type I collagen. Hyaline and elastic cartilages mainly contain type II collagen.

Collagen  Locations Mnemonic
Type I Bone, Fibrocartilage, Fascia, Tendon, Ligaments B-one
Type II Hyaline and Elastic cartilage Car-two-lage
Type III Reticular tissue Re-three-cular
Type IV Basement membrane Floor-four

questions.text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of:
questions.solution:
Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres.

The ligamenta flava are a series of ligaments that connect the ventral parts of the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. They predominantly contain elastic tissue and form part of the posterior surface of the vertebral canal. The high content of elastin allows it to be stretched by 80% without damage. The ligamentum flava resist separation of the laminae in flexion and assist in extension back to the anatomical position.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fibrous joint?
questions.solution:
The symphysis is not a fibrous joint, but a secondary cartilaginous joint. 

Structural classification of joints is as follows:

Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Cranial sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous joints (or synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous joints (or symphysis)
 Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

questions.text: What are synovial joints functionally classified as?
questions.solution:
Synovial joints are freely movable joints and therefore functionally classified as diarthrosis. 

Functional classification of joints:

  • Synarthroses - These are immovable. e.g., fibrous joints           
  • Amphiarthroses - They are slightly mobile. e.g., cartilaginous joints 
  • Diarthroses - These are freely mobile. e.g., synovial joints.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes a joint with three or more articular surfaces?
questions.solution:
A joint with three or more articular surfaces is classified as a compound joint.  

Classification of joints based on the number of articulating surfaces:

  • Simple joints have 2 articulation surfaces. e.g., shoulder joint, hip joint.
  • Compound joints have 3 or more articulation surfaces. e.g., elbow joint, wrist joint.
  • Complex joints have an intra-articular disc between the articular surfaces which divides the joint space. e.g., temporomandibular joint, sternoclavicular joint.

questions.text: Which of the following joints is known as a peg-and-socket joint?
questions.solution:
Gomphosis (dentoalveolar syndesmosis) is a peg-and-socket joint between a tooth and its socket. 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are joined together by fibrous tissue. They are further classified as sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis (see Table).

Classification of Fibrous joints
Subtype Description Examples
Sutures Peculiar to the skull. Bones are separated by a layer of membrane-derived connective tissue.
  • Plane - internasal suture
  • Serrate - interparietal suture
  • Squamous - temporoparietal suture
  • Denticulate - lambdoid suture
  • Schindylesis type, specialized suture in which a ridged bone fits into a groove on a neighboring bone - the cleft between the alae of the vomer receives the rostrum of the sphenoid
Syndesmosis There is a true fibrous connection between bones.
  • Connected by interosseous ligament - tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis
  • Connected by a dense fibrous membrane - posterior region of sacroiliac joint
Gomphosis A peg sits inside a socket supported by fibrous connections.
  • The tooth in its socket

The following image shows the types of fibrous joints:

questions.text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.solution:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.

In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint. 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 47-year-old lady diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis presented to the clinic with the following deformity. The joint involved in this condition is an example of_________
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is hallux valgus. This is caused due to an excessive lateral deviation at the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It is an example of an ellipsoid joint. 

Ellipsoid joints have an oval, convex (male) surface fitting into an elliptical concave (female) surface. They show biaxial movements such as flexion-extension, and abduction–adduction. A combination of these movements results in circumduction. Movement on the third axis is prevented due to the general articular shape.

E.g., Wrist (radiocarpal) joint, atlanto-occipital joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and metatarsophalangeal joints. 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: Forward and backward movements of the mandible that occur at the temporomandibular joint is called as______and ______, respectively.
questions.solution:
Forward and backward movement of the mandible that occurs at the temporomandibular joints are called as protraction and retraction, respectively. Protraction occurs when the lower jaw is pushed forward, while retraction pulls the lower jaw backward.

Protraction and retraction also occur in the scapula. During protraction, the scapula is moved laterally and anteriorly along the chest wall, such as during rowing movements. Retraction is bringing scapula back to the original position after protraction.

Option A: Opposition is the thumb movement that brings the tip of the thumb in contact with the tip of a finger. Returning the thumb to its anatomical position next to the index finger is called reposition. 

Option B: Excursion is the side to side movement of the mandible.

Option D: Depression and elevation are downward and upward movements of the mandible (or scapula), respectively.

questions.text: All of the following are rounded or irregular elevations of bones, except _______
questions.solution:
The styloid process is a sharp elevation of bone.

Bony elevations can be sharp or rounded:

  • Rounded or irregular elevations include a tubercle, tuberosity, epicondyle, malleolus, and trochanter.
  • Sharp elevations of bones include styloid process, spine, cornu (horn), and hamulus (hook-like).

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the image below is _________:
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint.

The various types of joints in the thoracic wall include:

Type of Joint  Examples 
Synovial joint

Costovertebral joint

Costotranverse joint

Interchondral joints
Primary cartilaginous joint/Synchondrosis Costochondral joint
Secondary cartilaginous/Symphyses joint Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints

Sternocostal joints: These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the sternum.

  • The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint (synarthrosis).
  • The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints.

The interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of the 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and is usually absent.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Articulations with the vertebrae

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the inferior costal facet of the vertebral body above
  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Rib 1: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 10, 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • 10th rib - upper border of the tenth thoracic vertebra near its pedicle
  • 11th, 12th ribs - Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8 - 10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum
